theoryTitle: Shanks Lost His Arm to Escape Imu's Control
theoryText: Based on revelations in One Piece Chapter 1152, fans theorize that Shanks didn't just lose his arm saving Luffy - he deliberately sacrificed it to free himself from the World Government's control. The theory suggests that Shanks had a mark (the 'Abyss mark') on his left arm granted by Imu, which allowed Imu to summon and control him at will. When the opportunity arose to save Luffy, Shanks willingly lost his marked arm, severing his connection to the Figarland family and Imu's influence. This recontextualizes the sacrifice: saving Luffy was genuine, but it also gave Shanks the perfect opportunity to gain his freedom. This explains why Shanks is so grateful to Luffy and why he 'bet his arm on the new era.'
originalPoster: Multiple fans across Reddit and anime forums
supportingEvidence: Chapter 1152 shows Shanks with a mark resembling the Holy Knights insignia on his left arm (the arm he lost)
The Abyss mark can only be granted by Imu and allows summoning/control of bearers
Saturn couldn't resist Imu's power, suggesting the mark's control is absolute
Shanks' words about 'betting on the new era' take on new meaning
Explains why such a powerful character would lose an arm to a relatively weak Sea King
counterEvidence: This theory is based on very recent manga chapters (1152) far beyond Episode 279
No direct confirmation from Oda yet
Could be coincidental resemblance rather than intentional connection

theoryTitle: Shanks Could Have Saved His Arm But Chose Not To
theoryText: Many fans theorize that Shanks, as one of the most powerful pirates in the world with mastery of all three types of Haki, could have easily defeated the Lord of the Coast without losing his arm. The theory suggests Shanks deliberately chose to lose his arm as a symbolic gesture - investing in Luffy's future and the new generation of pirates. By making such a dramatic sacrifice, Shanks ensured Luffy would understand the weight of dreams and the price people pay for them. Some versions of this theory suggest Shanks foresaw Luffy's potential (possibly through advanced Observation Haki) and made a calculated investment in the future Pirate King.
supportingEvidence: Shanks is later revealed to be a Yonko with immense power
He displays Conqueror's Haki in the same scene, scaring away the Sea King
Shanks tells Whitebeard he 'bet his arm on the new era'
The Sea King that took his arm is later easily defeated by a young, inexperienced Luffy
Shanks shows no regret about losing his arm when confronted by Whitebeard
counterEvidence: Shanks might not have had time to react properly while protecting Luffy
The scene shows genuine urgency and danger
Oda's editor suggested the arm loss for dramatic effect (meta reason)
No direct evidence of precognition or deliberate choice in the original scene

theoryTitle: The Lord of the Coast Will Be Important Later
theoryText: Some fans theorize that the Lord of the Coast - the Sea King that ate Higuma and took Shanks' arm - will have significance later in the series. Theories range from it being connected to the ancient weapons (since Sea Kings can communicate and are tied to Poseidon) to it potentially recognizing Luffy when he returns to Foosha Village as a legendary pirate. The most popular version suggests the Sea King witnessed something important about Luffy or Shanks that day and may serve as a witness or catalyst for future revelations about their connection.
supportingEvidence: Oda rarely includes details without purpose
Luffy defeats this same Sea King in Chapter 1/Episode 1, creating narrative symmetry
Sea Kings are later revealed to be intelligent and connected to ancient history
The creature witnessed Shanks using Conqueror's Haki
counterEvidence: The Sea King appears to be a relatively minor creature, not a sentient Sea King
Luffy's defeat of it in Chapter 1 may have been the narrative payoff
No subsequent appearances or references to this specific creature
Could simply be a narrative device rather than a plot-relevant character

theoryTitle: Oda's Editor Made Him Do It (Meta Theory)
theoryText: This is a confirmed meta-theory based on Oda's own statements. Originally, Oda had no plans for Shanks to lose his arm in the scene. However, his editor suggested that having Shanks sacrifice his arm would make the story more emotionally impactful and exciting. Oda agreed and made the change, creating one of the most iconic moments in the series. This theory is often cited by fans when discussing whether there's a deeper in-universe reason for the arm loss or if it was purely for dramatic storytelling effect.
supportingEvidence: Direct confirmation from Eiichiro Oda in interviews
Oda has acknowledged his editor's influence on early One Piece decisions
The dramatic impact of the scene is undeniable and set the tone for the series
counterEvidence: Oda may have later woven in-universe explanations for the decision
The meta reason doesn't preclude story-based reasons existing simultaneously
